deliberation: Checked whether the prophetic formula is purely literal. The phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me' treats 'word' as an active agent that can 'come,' which is a conventional personification/metonymy for divine revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a 'word' that comes/arrives like a person or messenger
ground: initiative and directed movement from sender to recipient
posture: emphasis on God’s initiative in revelation
instances.explanation: The 'word' is spoken of as if it were a being that can come to Ezekiel, personifying the message and metonymically standing for God’s act of revelation.

deliberation: Looked for pride imagery and divine-claim language. Found idiomatic/metaphorical uses of 'heart' and spatial imagery ('seat of God,' 'heart of the seas') used for status and security, plus a further metaphor of the king’s mind as a divine heart.

instances.english_text: Because your heart has been lifted up / because you have been so haughty
target: the king of Tyre’s inner attitude of pride
ground: being exalted above one’s proper place, arrogance
instances.explanation: The king’s pride is depicted as his 'heart' being lifted up, an idiomatic metaphor using vertical height to convey arrogant self-exaltation.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵל אָנִי מוֹשַׁב אֱלֹהִים יָשַׁבְתִּי בְּלֵב יַמִּים
instances.english_text: “I am a god; I sit enthroned like a god in the heart of the seas”
target: the king’s political-security status and royal rule in Tyre
vehicle: a divine throne located in the 'heart' of the seas
ground: supreme authority, unassailable central position, invulnerability
posture: exposing and critiquing the king’s presumptuous self-deification
instances.explanation: The king’s claim to sit in a 'seat of God' in the 'heart of the seas' metaphorically presents his rule over island-Tyre as a divine, centrally enthroned, invulnerable status.

instances.english_text: you deemed your mind equal to a god’s / you gave your heart as the heart of a god
ground: perceived boundless wisdom, autonomy, and authority
posture: judgment on the king’s blasphemous self-comparison to deity
instances.explanation: The king’s mind is metaphorically described as being like the heart of a god, depicting his claim to divine-level wisdom and status.

deliberation: Assessed whether the praise of wisdom is literal or exaggerated/ironic. The comparison 'wiser than Daniel' and 'no hidden matter' language appears deliberately overstated and sarcastic, functioning as hyperbolic irony rather than straightforward compliment.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה חָכָם אַתָּה מִדָּנִיאֵל כׇּל־סָתוּם לֹא עֲמָמֻךָ
instances.english_text: Yes, you are wiser than Daniel; in no hidden matter can anyone compare to you.
target: the king of Tyre’s vaunted wisdom
vehicle: comparison surpassing Daniel and knowing every hidden thing
ground: extreme, exaggerated degree of wisdom and insight
posture: ironic echoing of the king’s self-flattery to ridicule it
instances.explanation: The statement that he surpasses Daniel and that no secret is hidden from him is deliberately hyperbolic and ironic, mocking the king’s inflated self-image rather than sincerely praising him.

deliberation: Reviewed whether 'wisdom' and 'treasuries' are used figuratively. Here they describe literal economic skill and accumulated wealth without clear metaphorical or idiomatic usage beyond standard abstractions.
Considered trade language as literal and checked for idioms. The notable figurative element is again the idiomatic metaphor of the 'heart' being raised, expressing pride grounded in wealth.

instances.english_text: And you have grown haughty because of your wealth (your heart was lifted up in your wealth)
target: the king’s inner arrogance produced by riches
ground: being above others and above one’s proper station
posture: rebuke of pride that is grounded in material success
instances.explanation: The expression 'your heart was lifted up' uses height as a metaphor for haughtiness, an idiom describing arrogance rooted in wealth.

deliberation: Looked for repeated pride imagery. The verse reuses the 'heart like the heart of a god' wording, a metaphor/idiom for arrogating divine status to one’s inner counsel.

instances.english_text: Because you have deemed your mind equal to a god’s / Because you set your heart as the heart of God
target: the king’s mind and intentional stance toward himself
ground: claim to supreme wisdom, autonomy, and authority
instances.explanation: The king’s 'heart'—his inner mind—is likened to God’s heart, metaphorically expressing his claim to divine-level status and wisdom.

deliberation: Examined the violent imagery. The 'swords' are directed against the 'beauty of your wisdom' and 'splendor'—abstract qualities—so physical attack language is metaphorically applied to status/reputation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהֵרִיקוּ חַרְבוֹתָם עַל־יְפִי חׇכְמָתֶךָ וְחִלְּלוּ יִפְעָתֶךָ
instances.english_text: They shall unsheathe their swords against your prized shrewdness, and they shall strike down/profane your splendor.
target: the king’s prestigious wisdom, splendor, and public standing
vehicle: swords attacking beauty and splendor, and cultic 'profanation'
ground: violent removal and shaming of what was once admired and set apart
posture: announcement of humiliating judgment on the king’s vaunted status
instances.explanation: Swords cannot literally cut 'wisdom' or 'splendor'; the language metaphorically depicts military conquest as violently desecrating the king’s prestige and glory, using cultic 'profanation' imagery.

deliberation: Evaluated Sheol/grave imagery and death formula. 'Bring you down to the Pit' is a common metaphor for consigning someone to the realm of the dead. 'Death of the slain' is a set phrase for violent death, functioning idiomatically.

instances.english_text: They shall bring you down to the Pit
target: the king’s death and removal from life and power
ground: being cast down, trapped, and removed from the realm of the living
posture: portrays death as a humiliating downward movement under divine judgment
instances.explanation: Death is portrayed as being brought down into 'the Pit,' a conventional metaphor (and metonymy) for Sheol/the grave, emphasizing humiliation and total removal.

instances.english_text: In the heart of the sea you shall die the death of the slain
target: the manner of the king’s end
vehicle: standard formula for violent battlefield death
ground: violent, dishonorable killing rather than natural death
posture: underscores the shameful character of the king’s demise
instances.explanation: The phrase 'death of the slain' is an idiomatic formula for a violent, battle-like death, marking his end as disgraceful rather than peaceful.

deliberation: Considered whether the rhetorical question or 'before your slayers' language is figurative beyond rhetoric. The verse is a straightforward challenge contrasting his claim to deity with his obvious mortality at death; no distinct metaphor or idiom beyond prior 'I am a god' claim.
Looked at 'death of the uncircumcised' and 'by the hand of strangers.' Both are idiomatic: 'hand' for agency and 'uncircumcised' as a cultural-religious label standing for foreign, shameful death.

instances.english_text: You shall die the death of the uncircumcised
ground: shameful, alien, God-forsaken kind of end
posture: pronounces the king’s fate as that of a despised outsider
instances.explanation: Calling it 'the death of the uncircumcised' uses covenantal language to depict his death as shameful and foreign, not befitting his claims to divinity.

instances.english_text: by the hands of strangers
target: the agents who will kill the king
posture: indicates foreign powers as instruments of divine judgment
instances.explanation: 'Hand' stands metonymically for the effective power and agency of foreign nations who will execute him.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as v.1. Again the 'word of YHWH' is depicted as coming, which personifies the divine message.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: the act of God revealing a message
ground: intentional approach from sender to recipient
posture: stresses that the prophecy originates in God, not the prophet
instances.explanation: The 'word' is portrayed as an active subject that 'comes,' a standard personification and metonymy for God’s revelatory action.

deliberation: Looked at the lament introduction and descriptions of the king. 'Seal of perfection' is a clear metaphor, and 'full of wisdom, perfect in beauty' is hyperbolic idealization within that metaphorical frame.

instances.hebrew_text: אַתָּה חוֹתֵם תָּכְנִית מָלֵא חׇכְמָה וּכְלִיל יֹפִי
instances.english_text: You were the seal of perfection, full of wisdom and flawless in beauty.
target: the king of Tyre’s former exalted status and qualities
vehicle: a seal that perfectly imprints a pattern; flawless beauty
ground: completeness, exemplarity, nothing lacking or flawed
posture: presents his initial state as ideally exalted in order to heighten the tragedy of his fall
instances.explanation: Calling him 'the seal of perfection' and 'flawless in beauty' metaphorically idealizes the king as the perfect imprint of wisdom and beauty, using hyperbole to stress how high he once stood.

deliberation: Assessed whether Eden is literal or symbolic. The king is placed in 'Eden, the garden of God' and portrayed as adorned with precious stones—mythic-garden and jewel imagery functioning as an extended metaphor for paradisal, priestly-royal splendor.

instances.english_text: You were in Eden, the garden of God
target: the king’s exalted, privileged environment and status
ground: nearness to God, abundance, beauty, and privilege
posture: depicts his former state as paradisal in order to contrast his later fall
instances.explanation: Placing the historical king in 'Eden' is not literal geography but a metaphorical relocation to God’s primordial garden, symbolizing ideal nearness to God and fullness of blessing.

instances.hebrew_text: כׇּל־אֶבֶן יְקָרָה מְסֻכָתֶךָ ... זָהָב מְלֶאכֶת תֻּפֶּיךָ וּנְקָבֶיךָ בָּךְ
instances.english_text: Every precious stone was your adornment ... and gold beautifully wrought for you
target: the king’s glory and high status
vehicle: a garment or covering made of every kind of precious stone and gold workmanship
ground: extreme value, beauty, and honor, like a richly adorned high priest/king
posture: emphasizes how richly endowed and honored he was
instances.explanation: The list of precious stones and gold as his 'covering' metaphorically portrays his status as one clothed in unparalleled honor and value, likely echoing priestly-royal vestments.

deliberation: This verse is dense with mythic-cherubic imagery. The king is likened to an anointed cherub on God’s holy mountain, walking among 'stones of fire'—an extended metaphor mapping him onto a heavenly guardian in a dangerous sacred realm.

instances.english_text: I created you as a cherub with outstretched shielding wings / You were the anointed shielding cherub
target: the king’s protective, exalted office over Tyre
vehicle: anointed cherub who covers (guardian being with wings)
ground: exalted nearness to the divine, protective responsibility, consecration
posture: presents the king’s original calling as a divinely appointed, sacred guardian
instances.explanation: The king is metaphorically portrayed as an 'anointed cherub that covers,' mapping his royal office onto the image of a heavenly guardian of God’s presence.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּהַר קֹדֶשׁ אֱלֹהִים הָיִיתָ בְּתוֹךְ אַבְנֵי־אֵשׁ הִתְהַלָּכְתָּ
instances.english_text: You resided on God’s holy mountain; you walked among stones of fire.
target: the king’s exalted, perilous nearness to God and his privileged environment
vehicle: God’s holy mountain and fiery stones
ground: elevation, sacredness, glory, and danger in God’s immediate sphere
posture: underscores both the height of his position and the danger of his later fall
instances.explanation: Living on 'God’s holy mountain' and walking among 'stones of fire' symbolically describes his high, sacred, and dangerous proximity to the divine, not a literal geography.

deliberation: Explored whether 'your ways' is idiomatic. It follows the common biblical metaphor of life as a path, where 'ways' stands for moral conduct rather than literal routes.

instances.english_text: You were blameless in your ways
target: the king’s pattern of conduct and character
ground: a course of life analogous to a path one travels, with direction and choices
posture: evaluates his initial course of life as morally sound
instances.explanation: 'Ways' is an idiomatic metaphor for one’s conduct or manner of life, pictured as paths on which a person walks.

deliberation: Looked at trade language and the continuation of cherub/mountain imagery. The core figure is the removal of the 'covering cherub' from the divine mountain and fiery stones, continuing the metaphor of the king as a heavenly guardian expelled from God’s realm.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֲחַלֶּלְךָ מֵהַר אֱלֹהִים וָאַבֶּדְךָ כְּרוּב הַסֹּכֵךְ מִתּוֹךְ אַבְנֵי־אֵשׁ
instances.english_text: So I have struck you down from the mountain of God, and I have destroyed you, O shielding cherub, from among the stones of fire.
target: the king’s loss of office and expulsion from his exalted status
vehicle: a covering cherub being profaned and expelled from God’s mountain and fiery stones
ground: loss of sacred privilege, removal from God’s immediate presence and from a high place
posture: presents his judgment as a desecration and banishment from the divine realm
instances.explanation: The king, portrayed as a 'covering cherub,' is said to be profaned and destroyed from God’s mountain and fiery stones, metaphorically depicting his deposition as expulsion from a heavenly-sounding sacred realm.

deliberation: Examined pride and humiliation language. Found the idiom of the 'heart' being lifted by beauty, and the humiliation images of being cast to the ground and made a spectacle for kings.

instances.english_text: You grew haughty because of your beauty (your heart was lifted up in your beauty)
target: the king’s inner pride derived from his attractiveness/glory
ground: exaltation beyond proper measure, feeling above others
instances.explanation: As earlier, the 'heart' being lifted up is an idiomatic metaphor depicting arrogance, here explicitly tied to his beauty.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־אֶרֶץ הִשְׁלַכְתִּיךָ לִפְנֵי מְלָכִים נְתַתִּיךָ לְרַאֲוָה בָךְ
instances.english_text: I have cast you to the ground; I have made you an object for kings to stare at.
target: the king’s humiliation and public disgrace
vehicle: a body thrown to the ground and displayed as a spectacle
ground: from high to low, exposed helplessly, subject to others’ gaze and contempt
posture: depicts God’s judgment as utter humiliation before other rulers
instances.explanation: Being 'cast to the ground' and made into a spectacle for kings metaphorically portray his reversal from exalted status to humiliating public disgrace.

deliberation: Considered trade and sanctuary language. Focused on the internal fire imagery—'I made a fire issue from you; it has devoured you; I made you ashes'—as metaphorical for self-destructive judgment culminating in total ruin.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאוֹצִא־אֵשׁ מִתּוֹכְךָ הִיא אֲכָלַתְךָ וָאֶתֶּנְךָ לְאֵפֶר עַל־הָאָרֶץ
instances.english_text: So I made a fire issue from you, and it has devoured you; I have reduced you to ashes on the ground
target: the king’s destruction brought on by his own guilt and by God’s judgment
vehicle: a fire coming out from within a person and consuming him until only ashes remain
ground: judgment arising from within his own corrupt state, leading to complete ruin
self-destructive consequences and totality of loss
posture: portrays his end as both deserved (from within) and total under God’s hand
instances.explanation: The image of a fire issuing from inside him to devour him, leaving only ashes, metaphorically depicts his own guilt and God’s judgment consuming him to utter ruin, with hyperbolic stress on total destruction.

deliberation: Checked for imagery in the reaction of nations. 'You have become a horror' is metaphorical—he himself is not literally a terror-entity but a symbol that evokes horror; 'you are not forever' reads as prophetic hyperbole about his political annihilation.

instances.english_text: You have become a horror and have ceased to be, forever.
target: the king/kingdom’s post-judgment reputation and status
vehicle: a 'horror' and a state of non-existence
ground: others recoil in dread at your fate; politically you are as good as gone
posture: underscores the exemplary, terrifying nature of his downfall
instances.explanation: The king is said to 'become a horror' and to no longer exist forever; this is metaphorical and hyperbolic for his becoming an object of dread and his effective annihilation from the political stage.

deliberation: Same formula as vv.1 and 11: again, 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies the divine message as a coming agent.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: God’s act of communicating with Ezekiel
ground: initiative, directedness, and agency in communication
posture: asserts divine origin and authority for what follows
instances.explanation: The phrase again personifies the 'word' as if it travels to the prophet, a conventional figurative way to speak of divine revelation.

deliberation: Evaluated 'set your face toward Sidon' as possible idiom. It’s a standard prophetic idiom for turning one’s attention and stance resolutely toward a target of judgment.

instances.english_text: set your face toward Sidon
target: Ezekiel’s prophetic focus and stance toward Sidon
vehicle: directing one’s physical face toward someone
ground: fixing attention and intention firmly on a person/object
posture: signals a deliberate, confrontational prophetic address to Sidon
instances.explanation: Setting one’s 'face' toward a city is an idiomatic metaphor for turning one’s attention and confrontational stance toward it in prophetic speech.

deliberation: Reviewed whether glory/holiness language is figurative. 'I will be glorified in your midst' and 'I will be sanctified in her' use cultic terms metonymically for God’s reputation and recognition among the nations through judgment.

instances.english_text: I will gain glory in your midst ... and show Myself holy through her.
target: how God is perceived and acknowledged among Sidon and the nations
vehicle: receiving honor and recognition of holiness
ground: God’s holiness and sovereignty becoming publicly recognized through His acts
posture: asserts that judgment on Sidon will function as a public vindication of God’s holiness
instances.explanation: To be 'glorified' and 'sanctified' in or through a nation is metonymic for God’s character being recognized and honored as holy because of His judgments.

deliberation: Looked at pestilence and sword language. 'The sword comes upon her from all sides' uses 'sword' as a metonymy for war/invading armies; letting pestilence loose also slightly personifies the plague as an agent sent.

instances.english_text: I will let pestilence loose against her ... when the sword comes upon her from all sides.
target: the military and plague judgments on Sidon
vehicle: pestilence 'sent' and a sword that 'comes upon' a city
plague and weapon acting as agents
ground: God directs destructive forces, especially war ('sword') and plague, as if they were His commissioned agents
posture: depicts war and plague as God’s tools against Sidon
instances.explanation: 'Sword' stands metonymically for invading armies and warfare, and both sword and pestilence are slightly personified as agents 'sent' or 'coming upon' the city by God.

deliberation: Identified the thorn/brier imagery. Neighboring hostile nations are depicted as 'prickling briers' and 'lacerating thorns'—a sustained metaphor for persistent, painful harassment.

instances.hebrew_text: סִלּוֹן מַמְאִיר וְקוֹץ מַכְאִב מִכֹּל סְבִיבֹתָם הַשָּׁאטִים אוֹתָם
instances.english_text: prickling briers and lacerating thorns from all the neighbors who despise them
target: the hostile surrounding nations that afflict Israel
ground: constant irritation, wounding, and difficulty of removal
posture: promises relief from the painful oppression of hostile nations
instances.explanation: Hostile neighboring peoples are metaphorically described as briers and thorns, emphasizing their role in wounding and irritating Israel.

deliberation: Considered the gathering and sanctification language. The gathering from nations is literal exile-return imagery; 'I will be sanctified in them in the sight of the nations' again uses holiness terminology metonymically for God’s reputation being vindicated.

instances.english_text: and have shown Myself holy through them in the sight of the nations
target: how God is known and regarded among the nations through Israel’s restoration
vehicle: being 'sanctified' in or through a people
ground: God’s uniqueness and holiness becoming evident through His historical actions on Israel’s behalf
posture: presents restoration as a means of publicly vindicating God’s holiness
instances.explanation: To be 'sanctified' in Israel before the nations is a metonymy for God’s holiness being recognized and honored as He restores His people.

deliberation: Evaluated the security and prosperity language. 'Dwell in security' is idiomatic, and building houses/planting vineyards functions as a metonymy/synecdoche for a stable, prosperous settled life under divine protection.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָשְׁבוּ עָלֶיהָ לָבֶטַח וּבָנוּ בָתִּים וְנָטְעוּ כְּרָמִים וְיָשְׁבוּ לָבֶטַח
instances.english_text: and they shall dwell on it in security. They shall build houses and plant vineyards, and shall dwell on it in security
target: Israel’s future state of rest, stability, and prosperity in the land
vehicle: dwelling 'securely' and engaging in house‑building and vineyard‑planting
ground: freedom from threat enabling normal, productive life and long‑term investment
posture: promises comprehensive peace and prosperity under God’s protection
instances.explanation: Living 'securely' and building houses and vineyards is idiomatic and metonymic for a settled, unthreatened, and prosperous existence in the land.
